properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Bunyip River downstream of Iona.

  • The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about       42 mm since 09:00 AM Sunday 14 August 2022. 
  •  Rainfall totals of 5-15 mm are forecast for the catchment Monday       15 August 2022. Further rainfall totals of 5-15mm are forecast for Tuesday 16 August.

Bunyip River downstream of Iona:

  • The level of the Bunyip River at Cora Lynn is currently at 3.69 metres, and rising. It is expected to peak above the Minor Flood Level (3.10 metres) Monday evening.
  • Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn is closed to traffic.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • The South Gippsland Highway at Caldermeade is closed to outbound traffic and spreed restrictions are in place.
  • Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is expected to affect low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn may be closed to traffic on Monday.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Bunyip River downstream of Iona:
- The level of the Bunyip River at Cora Lynn is currently at 3.69 metres, and rising. It is expected to peak above the Minor Flood Level (3.10 metres) Monday evening.
- Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn is closed to traffic. 


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Moe River at Darnum. 

  • MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING IN THE MOE RIVER AT DARNUM.
  • In the 24 hours to 03:00 pm Monday, rainfall totals of up to 20-50 mm have been recorded in the Latrobe River catchment. Further widespread rainfall totals of 5-10 mm are forecast for the reminder of Monday.
Moe River:

The Moe River at Darnum is currently at 4.42 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. The river level is expected to fall below the moderate flood level (4.00 m) later this afternoon.
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:

Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 

If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 

If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 

If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:  

Moderate flood breaks out of the Moe River near Darnum

North Canal Road - Yarragon, South Canal Road-Trafalgar Little Moe River Road- Darnum, Rhodes Road-Darnum, Silbys Road-Darnum, Eight Mile Road-Trafalgar, Mahoneys Road-Yarragon

  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.


This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Tarago River.

  • The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 42 mm since 09:00 AM Sunday 14 August 2022.  
  • Rainfall totals of 5-15 mm are forecast for the catchment Monday 15 August 2022. Further rainfall totals of 5-15mm are forecast for Tuesday 16 August.
Tarago River:

  • The level of Tarago Reservoir is currently at 158.00 metres, above the spillway level of 157.92 metres.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is expected to affect low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway.The ford at Cora Lynn may be closed to traffic on Monday.
  • The South Gippsland Highway is closed outbound at Caldermeade Road due to flooding. Please follow the direction of traffic management and detour via Caldermeade Road. The right lane citybound is also closed. 
  • Never drive through flood water.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 06:10 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Latrobe River downstream of Traralgon.

Minor Flooding possible in the Latrobe River at Rosedale overnight Monday into Tuesday

In the 24 hours to 03:00 pm Monday, rainfall totals of up to 20-50 mm have been recorded in the Latrobe River catchment. Further widespread rainfall totals of 5-10 mm are forecast for the reminder of Monday.

Latrobe River downstream of Traralgon:
  • Minor flooding may occur along the Latrobe River downstream of Traralgon.
  • The Latrobe River at Rosedale (Main Stream) is currently at 2.89 metres and rising. The Latrobe River at Rosedale (Main Stream) may exceed the minor flood level (4.00 m) overnight Monday into Tuesday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • For information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Coast - Marlo to the Victoria-New South Wales Border
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for coastal water from Marlo to the Victoria-New South Wales Border.

  • The levels of blue green algae within the Gippsland Lakes have decreased to below safe contact thresholds. The entire Gippsland Lakes system and ocean is now safe for recreational contact with the water.
  • It is important to note that advice regarding the consumption of specific seafood remains in place.
Do not eat prawns from affected waters.

These prawns may have come from the Gippsland Lakes and Ninety Mile Beach area and may contain toxins from the recent blue green algae bloom.

Do to not consume prawns caught within 10 nautical miles of the shore between Mcloughlins Beach and the Victoria-New South Wales border.
What you should do:
  • Visit betterhealth.vic.gov.au for more information.
  • Keep up-to-date with algae information at www.water.vic.gov.au/waterways-and-catchments/rivers-estuaries-andwaterways/blue-green-algae
Protect your health:
If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 19/08/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

- It is important to note that advice regarding the consumption of specific seafood remains in place. 



Do not eat prawns from affected waters.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for the Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek. 

Minor Flooding is expected in the Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge Monday afternoon. Moderate Flooding is possible Monday night.

In the 24 hours to 03:00 pm Monday, rainfall totals of up to 20-50 mm have been recorded in the Latrobe River catchment. Further widespread rainfall totals of 5-10 mm are forecast for the reminder of Monday.

Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek:
  • Moderate flooding may occur along the Latrobe River Yallourn to Traralgon Creek.
  • The Latrobe River at Thoms Bridge is currently at 3.82 metres and rising. It is expected to exceed the minor flood level (4.00 m) Monday afternoon, and may reach the moderate flood level (5.00 m) Monday night.

This Watch and Act message replaces the Advice Message issued at 12:03 pm. 
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:

  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 

If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 

If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 

If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:  
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding. Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Gippsland Lakes and the Gippsland Coast from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo
properties.webBody:
Thismessageis being issued for water in the Gippsland Lakes and the Ninety Mile Beach from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo.

  • The levels of blue green algae within the Gippsland Lakes have decreased to well below the safe contact thresholds.
  • The entire Gippsland Lakes system and Ninety Mile Beach is now safe for recreational contact with water.
  • However as toxins from the algae can accumulate in seafood after a bloom has dispersed, advice regarding the consumption of specific seafood still applies.
Do not consume crustaceans (such as prawns, crabs and bugs) and shellfish caught inside the Gippsland Lakes or within 10 nautical miles of the shore between Mcloughlins Beach and Marlo.

Finfish caught from within the Gippsland Lakes should be rinsed thoroughly in fresh water and the guts and gills removed before cooking or freezing.

Ingesting these toxins can lead to serious illness. Cooking or freezing does not destroy the toxins.
What you should do:
  • Visit betterhealth.vic.gov.au (https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/harmful-algal-blooms) for more information.
  • Keep up-to-date with algae information at www.water.vic.gov.au/waterways-and-catchments/rivers-estuaries-and-waterways/blue-green-algae
Protect your health:
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call (https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/primary-and-community-health/primary-care/nurse-on-call) on 130060 60 24.
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 19/08/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Kiewa River at Bandiana.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT BANDIANA

Minor flooding is expected to continue along the Kiewa River at Bandiana during Monday.

Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge.

The Kiewa River at Bandiana is currently at 2.88 metres and steady, with minor flooding. The Kiewa River at Bandiana is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.80 m) during Monday.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams. 
  • Low lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Low lying areas next to water courses become inundated which may require the removal of stock and equipment
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Flood Advice is being issued for Caldermeade at South Gippsland Highway.

  • Flooding is occurring at South Gippsland Highway, Caldermeade.
  • The South Gippsland Highway is closed outbound at Caldermeade       Road due to flooding. 
  • Please follow the direction of emergency services and never drive       through flood water.
  • Speed has been reduced to 40 kilometres per hour.
  • Surrounding roads may also be impacted by across water flooding.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes. 
  • For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
Impacts in your area
  • Areas around rivers, streams and drains may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • South Gippsland Highway north bound lane has been closed due to floodwater. For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service 

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 03:50 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (Vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Caldermeade_South Gippsland Highway
Issue Date: Monday 15 August 2022, 03:44 pm
Next Update: Tuesday 16 August 2022, 03:50 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/21184/moreinfo

This Flood Advice is being issued for Caldermeade at South Gippsland Highway.

- Flooding is occurring at South Gippsland Highway, Caldermeade.
- The South Gippsland Highway is closed outbound at Caldermeade       Road due to flooding. 
- Please follow the direction of emergency services and never drive       through flood water. 
- Speed has been reduced to 40 kilometres per hour.
- Surrounding roads may also be impacted by across water flooding.


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River at Corowa.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT COROWA   

Spills from the Hume Dam combined with flood waters from the Kiewa River have caused minor flooding along the Murray River at Corowa. 
At Corowa, river levels are likely to remain steady above the minor flood level (4.60 metres) through to the end of the week.   

The Murray River at Albury is expected to remain below the minor flood level (4.30 metres).   

River levels downstream of Corowa are likely to remain below minor flood levels.   

Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal: 
Minor flooding is occurring along the Murray River at Corowa.   

The Murray River at Corowa is likely to remain near 5.40 metres through to the end of the week, with minor flooding.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. 

For more information relevant to your area please check www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Low lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/08/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Bunyip River to Iona.

  • The Bunyip River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 42 mm since 09:00 AM Sunday 14 August 2022. 
  •  Rainfall totals of 5-15 mm are forecast for the catchment Monday 15 August 2022. 
  • Further rainfall totals of 5-15mm are forecast for Tuesday 16 August.

Bunyip River to Iona:

The level of the Bunyip River at Iona is currently at 2.29 metres, and rising. It is expected to peak above the Minor Flood Level (2.10 metres) early Monday evening.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Traralgon Creek.

Minor Flooding is occurring along the Traralgon Creek at Traralgon Town.

    In the 48 hours to 3:00 pm Monday, widespread rainfall totals of 50-100 mm have been been recorded in the Traralgon Creek catchment. A further 5-10 mm is forecast for the remainder of Monday.
    The Traralgon Creek at Traralgon peaked at 3.87 metres around 08:30 am Monday 15 August and is currently at 3.67 metres and falling, with minor flooding. It is expected to remain above the minor flood level (3.50 m) Monday afternoon. The river level is likely to fall below the minor flood level (3.50 m) Monday night.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

Minor flood breaks out of Traralgon Creek

  • Bert Thompson Reserve, Eric Taylor Reserve, Victory Park and Newman Park may experience some flooding. 
  • Flooding may cut access to Eton Avenue, also cutting access to Tintern Place and Salisbury Crescent, north west of Traralgon. 
  • Deep flooding may cut access to Whittakers Road. 
  • Shallow flooding may start to over top Franklin Street and Paul Street.

  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home may occur in some locations. 
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/08/2022 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Victoria. 
  • Varroa mite (Varroa destructor) has been found in New South Wales. 
  • This message is relevant for all beekeepers, associated beekeeping businesses and orchard owners.  
  • Restrictions are now in place for the movement of bees, beehives, beekeeping equipment and bee products. 
  • Victoria is currently free from Varroa mite. 
  • An Order declaring Victoria as a Control Area is now in place to prevent Varroa mite from coming into Victoria from NSW. 
  • You must have a permit to bring bees, beehives, beekeeping equipment and bee products into Victorias Sunraysia region. 
  • Check your hives regularly for signs of Varroa mite and other exotic pests. 
  • If you already have bees in the Sunraysia region, you must still apply for a permit. 
  • To view a map of the Sunraysia region, visit: here.
  • Existing certification requirements for moving bees, hives, used beekeeping equipment and bee products into Victoria still apply. 
  • For more information and to apply for a permit, visit https://agriculture.vic.gov.au/varroa.
What you need to know about Varroa mite:  
  • Varroa mite (Varroa destructor) is an exotic parasite of honey bees that weakens and kills honey bees and transmits honey bee viruses. 
  • If left untreated, Varroa mite infested honey bee hives are likely to die within three to four years, which will have a significant impact on Australia's honey and honey bee pollination plant industries. 
  • A permit is required to move bees, beehives, beekeeping equipment and bee products into Victoria from another state or from anywhere in Victoria into the Sunraysia region. Permits applications are currently being accepted from Victoria, South Australia and Queensland. This measure has been put in place ahead of Victorias almond pollination season.
  • No permits are being granted to NSW beekeepers at this time.
  • Agriculture Victoria will be repatriating some Victorian hives that have been stuck over the NSW border under permit (for details see https://agriculture.vic.gov.au/varroa). 
  • These measures have been made ahead of almond pollination season to provide extra care that we conduct this pollination season safely. 
  • This does not include processed honey and wax and new beekeeping tools and equipment which can be transported within Victoria and from interstate as normal. 

What you should do if you own bees: 
  • Check your hives regularly for signs of Varroa mite and other exotic pests. 
  • Varroa mite (Varroa destructor), is a distinctive-looking small mite, around 1 mm in diameter. 
  • Mites are easily identifiable to the naked eye and are a reddish-brown colour. 
  • Varroa mite can be tested for using any of the following methods:  sugar shake, alcohol wash test, drone uncapping or brood uncapping inspection. This should ideally be done at a temperature greater than 14C. 
  • If you see or suspect Varroa mite, report it immediately by calling the Exotic Plant Pest Hotline on 1800 084 881. This hotline is answered 0800 - 1800 Monday to Friday and 1000 - 1800 weekends and public holidays. Please leave a message outside of these hours.
What you should do if you are an orchardist receiving bees for pollination services: 
  • Orchard owners must ensure that bees coming to their property have a permit. 
Signs of the disease in bees may include: 
  • If present in a hive, Varroa mite can be found inside sealed brood cells, where they spend most of their life, multiply and feed on developing pupa. 
  • Female mites can also be found on adult bees. They often hide between the hardened abdominal segments closest to the thorax. 
  • The mites may be found on adult bees in overwintering colonies that have no honey bee brood.
How Varroa mite spreads:  
  • Varroa mite spreads between colonies and apiaries when hive components, infested brood and adult bees are interchanged; via the transport of hives, used beekeeping equipment; and queen bees and by foraging and drifting bees and swarms.
To help prevent the spread of Varroa mite to your bees you should:
  • Ensure that you have a permit if moving bees, hives, used beekeeping equipment and bee products into Victoria. All beekeepers are encouraged to be vigilant and inspect their hives regularly for signs of Varroa mite by using the sugar shake test, alcohol wash test, drone uncapping or brood uncapping inspection. This should ideally be done at a temperature greater than 14C.
Protecting your health: 
  • Varroa mite poses no risk to human health.
More Information:

This message was issued by Victorias Chief Plant Health Officer at the Department of Jobs, Precincts and Regions.   

The next update is expected as the situation changes.   

Agriculture Victoria website: agriculture.vic.gov.au/varroa 
NSW website: https://www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/varroa   

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky 

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: COMMUNITY INFORMATION - PLANT PEST - Stay Informed Incident Location: Victoria Issue Date: Thursday 28 July 2022, 09:36 am Next Update: Sunday 21 August 2022, 05:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/20993/moreinfo This message is being issued for Victoria. - Varroa mite (Varroa destructor) has been found in New South Wales. - This message is relevant for all beekeepers, associated beekeeping businesses and orchard owners. - Restrictions are now in place for the movement of bees, beehives, beekeeping equipment and bee products. - Victoria is currently free from Varroa mite. - An Order declaring Victoria as a Control Area is now in place to prevent Varroa mite from coming into Victoria from NSW. - You must have a permit to bring bees, beehives, beekeeping equipment and bee products into Victorias Sunraysia region. - Check your hives regularly for signs of Varroa mite and other exotic pests. - If you already have bees in the Sunraysia region, you must still apply for a permit. - To view a map of the Sunraysia region, visit: here. - Existing certification requirements for moving bees, hives, used beekeeping equipment and bee products into Victoria still apply. - For more information and to apply for a permit, visit https://agriculture.vic.gov.au/varroa.
